A "Worst-Case Scenario Offsite Consequence Analysis" and an "Alternative Scenario Offsite Consequence Analysis" were performed identifying the public and environmental receptors within the toxic endpoint concentration radius of 200 ppm.  The results are mitigated by the fact that most of the refrigeration equipment is inside the Suffolk, Virginia facility's building. 

Sara Lee has a detailed Emergency Action Plan (EAP) for their facility.  The purpose of this plan is to provide the means for rapidly determining the appropriate actions for any emergency that may develop at the facility such as an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Sara Lee conducts training and drills of the emergency action plan on a regular basis or when the plan changes.

 
To address the five year accident history is not an issue, since the facility is only 2 years old and has no history of reportable ammonia releases.  To prevent and/or minimize any potential future release of anhydrous ammonia, Sara Lee is implementing a detailed Process Safety Management program (Preventative Program 3) developed for their facility in Suffolk, Virginia.  The Preventative Program 3 provides extensive maintenance and operator/mechanic training to ensure that the system's mechanical integrity is maintained for the life of the covered process.  Program 3 also incorporates administrative controls when modifications are made to the covered process (ammonia refrigeration system), so that the training and preventative programs are updated as the system expands and changes.

Sara Lee will incorporate or address any recommendations resulting from the Process Hazard Analysis, incident investigations and program audits.

The flexibility of the program allows Sara Lee to respond effectively to prevent or minimize any potential of exposing Sara Lee employees, the surrounding public, and/or the environment to a release of anhydrous ammonia.
